title: LEVEL 2: CSS Foundations
description: Style your content with the Box Model and Selectors

lessons.title: 2.1 The Box Model
lessons.content:
# Everything is a Box

In CSS, every element is considered a rectangular box. Understanding the **Box Model** is critical for spacing components.

## 1. The Layers
- **Content**: The actual text or image.
- **Padding**: Transparent space inside the border (pushes content away from edge).
- **Border**: A line surrounding the padding and content.
- **Margin**: Space outside the border (pushes other elements away).

## 2. Box Sizing
By default, adding padding makes a box bigger. Use `box-sizing: border-box;` to include padding/border within the total width.
lessons.expectedOutput: A light blue box with spacing inside and outside.

quizQuestions.text: Which property adds space INSIDE the border?
quizQuestions.explanation: Padding is the space between the content and its border.

lessons.title: 3.1 Display Flex
lessons.content:
# Flexbox Basics

Flexbox is a 1-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns.

## 1. Activation
`display: flex;` on the parent container.

## 2. Main Axis (Horizontal by default)
- `justify-content: center`: Center items horizontally.
- `justify-content: space-between`: Push items to the edges.

## 3. Cross Axis (Vertical by default)
- `align-items: center`: Center items vertically.
lessons.expectedOutput: A professional dark navbar with a logo on the left and spaced-out links on the right.

quizQuestions.text: Which property centers items horizontally in a standard row flexbox?
quizQuestions.explanation: justify-content handles alignment along the main axis (horizontal in a row).

title: LEVEL 8: Accessibility & Forms
description: Create inclusive and functional web applications

lessons.title: 8.1 Semantic Forms & A11y
lessons.content:
# Accessible Forms

Forms are how users interact with your app. They must be usable by everyone, including screen reader users.

## 1. Essential Form Tags
- `<label>`: Always link to an input using the `for` attribute.
- `<fieldset>` & `<legend>`: Group related inputs.
- `required`: Built-in HTML validation.

## 2. ARIA Roles
Accessible Rich Internet Applications (ARIA) provide extra context.
`aria-label="Close menu"` on a button with only an icon.
lessons.fullProgram:
<!-- Accessible Signup Form -->
<form>
    <label for="email">Email Address:</label>
    <input type="email" id="email" name="email" required>
    
    <label for="pass">Password:</label>
    <input type="password" id="pass" name="pass" minlength="8">
    
    <button type="submit">Join GenSpark</button>
</form>
lessons.expectedOutput: A clean, functional form that works well with keyboards and screen readers.

quizQuestions.text: Why should you use <label for='id'> instead of just text next to an input?
options: It makes the input clickable via the label and aids screen readers
quizQuestions.explanation: Labels increase the clickable area and allow screen readers to correctly identify what the input is for.
